question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
Calculate the following derivative. You may leave your answer
unsimplified.

$\displaystyle f'(9)$, where $\displaystyle f(x)=g(x)x^{1/2}$,
$\displaystyle g(9)=2$, and $\displaystyle g'(9)=4$.
sols:
We apply the product rule to $f(x)$ to get:

$\displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x)*x^{1/2} + g(x)*(1/2)(x^{-1/2})$

Now we simply evaluate at \emph{x = 9}, using the other information
given in the problem to fill in \emph{g(9)} and \emph{g'(9)}. Recall
also that $x^{1/2} = \sqrt{x}$.

\begin{align*}
f'(9) &= g'(9)*(9)^{1/2} + g(9)*(1/2)(9^{-1/2})\\
&= 4 *3 + 2 *(1/2)(1/3) \\
&= 12 + 1/3
\end{align*}

So the value of $\displaystyle f'(9)$ is $37/3$.
hints:
To take the derivative of $f(x)$ you'll need the product rule. Remember
that the derivative of $g(x)$ is $g'(x)$.
